security_audit.summary: This is a legitimate static application security testing (SAST) skill for the Semgrep tool. The skill consists entirely of documentation, YAML configuration templates, and CI/CD pipeline examples. There are no executable scripts in this skill package. All functionality relies on the external Semgrep tool which users install separately. The skill is designed for local code scanning with no network data exfiltration or credential access.

content.value_statement: Detecting security vulnerabilities in code requires specialized tools and deep security knowledge. Semgrep provides fast, pattern-based static analysis across 30+ languages. This skill bundles OWASP and CWE mappings, CI/CD configurations, and remediation guides to make security scanning accessible.
actual_capabilities: Scan codebases for security vulnerabilities across 30+ languages
Map findings to OWASP Top 10 and CWE categories
Generate JSON and SARIF reports for security dashboards
Create custom security rules for organization patterns
Integrate security scanning into GitHub, GitLab, and Jenkins CI/CD
Provide remediation guidance for identified vulnerabilities
limitations: Requires Semgrep to be installed separately (pip install semgrep)
Does not perform dynamic or interactive security testing
Scan accuracy depends on available rulesets and custom rules
Does not replace manual security code review for complex issues

output_examples.input: Run a security scan on my codebase using Semgrep with security-audit rules

best_practices: Start with a baseline scan to establish current security state before enforcing gates
Use targeted rulesets for CI (p/ci) for fast feedback and comprehensive rules (p/security-audit) for deep reviews
Combine SAST with DAST, SCA, and manual review for defense in depth
anti_patterns: Running full scans on every commit without baseline filtering creates noise
Ignoring MEDIUM severity findings allows vulnerabilities to accumulate
Skipping false positive tuning discourages team adoption of security scanning

faq.question: Which languages does Semgrep support?
faq.answer: Semgrep supports 30+ languages including JavaScript, TypeScript, Python, Java, Go, Ruby, PHP, C#, and infrastructure as code like Terraform and Docker.

faq.question: How do I install Semgrep?
faq.answer: Install via pip: pip install semgrep, or use Docker: docker run returntocorp/semgrep semgrep --config=auto /path/to/code.

faq.question: Can I integrate with GitHub Security?
faq.answer: Yes, use the semgrep/semgrep-action@v1 GitHub Action which uploads results as SARIF to GitHub Security tab.

faq.question: Is my code sent to external servers?
faq.answer: Semgrep runs locally by default. Cloud rulesets are downloaded but code is not uploaded unless using Semgrep Cloud with explicit authentication.

faq.question: Why am I seeing false positives?
faq.answer: Create .semgrepignore for test code, use --exclude-rule to disable noisy rules, and add # nosemgrep comments for confirmed false positives.

faq.question: How does this compare to other SAST tools?
faq.answer: Semgrep is faster and uses pattern-based matching. Unlike some tools, it supports custom rules and integrates easily with existing workflows.
